Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Dharmaraká¹£a of the Western Jin Dynasty
The Buddha said to Akasagarbha: Can you now encompass all sentient beings?
Akasagarbha said:
Following the Buddha's holy intent, I am fully able to receive and accept.

As soon as Bodhisattva Akasagarbha entered samÄdhi, all the physical bodies, offerings, flowers, incense, silk canopies, banners, and flags all entered his navel, and his body remained as before, neither increasing nor decreasing.
There was a bodhisattva named MahÄÅ›uddha who asked Akasagarbha:
What is the name of the samÄdhi you have entered?
You manifest transformations and are able to receive all physical bodies, flowers, incense, banners, and canopies, yet your body remains as before, neither increasing nor decreasing.
Akasagarbha said:
That samÄdhi is called 'Universal Reception of Physical Bodies.'
MahÄÅ›uddha asked again:
Can this samÄdhi only receive this, or can it also receive other things?
AÅ›vaghoá¹£a said:
The trichiliocosm is all contained within the body, yet its location is not seen.
Why is this?
It is due to the majestic spiritual power, without any increase or decrease.

At that time, the assembly of devas, humans, bodhisattvas, and Å›rÄvakas all had thoughts, just like those who have long been thirsty and think of drinking, wanting to see the spiritual transformations manifested by the great being.
The Buddha knew the thoughts of the assembly and said to AÅ›vaghoá¹£a:
Manifest this samÄdhi for all people.
AÅ›vaghoá¹£a said:
I will respectfully follow the holy teaching.

At that time, the bodhisattvas, buddhas, and assemblies from the ten directions all saw themselves sitting in Achimota's navel. In Achimota's navel, there was a land called Universal Adornment, and the bodhisattvas' robes were like those of the bodhisattvas in the Adorned Land. They were all also present in his navel, and what was revealed was as majestic as the Universal Adornment.
After displaying the awesome transformation, the assembly each returned to their seats as before.
The bodhisattva Great Purity said to Achimota:
The holy grace and virtue of samadhi are so extraordinary that the light is like this.
Achimota said:
This is nothing to speak of.
Why is that?
The lands and mountains of the trichiliocosm can all contain the subtle dust of the physical body, and they are not cramped by the sands of the Ganges, let alone anything else.

When the chapter on patience and the supernormal powers were expounded, seventy koá¹­is of kind and gentle people gave rise to the aspiration for the Great Vehicle, and twelve thousand bodhisattvas all attained the acceptance that dharmas are not produced from anywhere.
ÅšÄriputra asked AÅ›vaghoá¹£a:
I wish to hear again about the bodhisattvas' inexhaustible diligence.
AÅ›vaghoá¹£a said:
There are eight kinds of inexhaustible diligence for bodhisattvas.
What are the eight?

First, wearing the armor of great virtue of vast vows is called diligence and inexhaustibility. Second, gathering diligence without retreating. Third, diligently studying and cultivating all merits. Fourth, always wishing to nurture and include all beings. Fifth, creating innumerable sources of blessings and merits. Sixth, the mind originally seeks the perfections without limit. Seventh, understanding wisdom is inexhaustible. Eighth, wishing to fully understand all Buddha-dharmas and therefore being inexhaustible. These eight kinds of diligence are called inexhaustibility.
AÅ›vaghoá¹£a said:
The reason it is called wearing the armor of vast vows is because it does not consider birth and death to be troublesome.
Why is it so?
It does not count the number of eons to become a Buddha, nor does it think about practicing bodhisattva deeds for so many eons.
The reason it is called vast vows is because it does not limit the immeasurable eons to be long or short.

Bodhisattvas are still the basis of all, and the number of days in the world changes, from one day to fifteen days, or thirty days to make a month, and twelve months to make a year. In this way, it progresses to a hundred thousand years, or a million years, and those who give rise to the intention to seek the Way all count this number, and after many eons they see a Buddha.

In this way, the number of people who first give rise to the intention, equal to the sands of the Ganges River, each gives rise to the intention and each completely embraces them. The bodhisattvas equal to the sands of the Ganges River are also like this. The innumerable and incalculable people who all give rise to the intention only know one thing, and the things they do not know are beyond measure.

It is like making offerings to Buddhas equal to the sands of the Ganges River, and then perfecting the perfection of giving, precepts, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom, and the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment are also like this;
When bodhisattvas hear this, their minds do not become lax or abandon the great virtue of the armor of vows.
People as numerous as the sands of the Ganges all give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, and the merit accumulated from this can be used to perfect one of the major marks of a great person;

in this way, all of them, each with the merit from before, are completely endowed with all the major marks of a great person - the great person referred to is the bodhisattva. When bodhisattvas hear this, they do not consider it to be troublesome.
Why is this?
Because they have never violated or abandoned the armor of vows, this is called the inexhaustibility of the bodhisattvas' donning of the armor of vows.
What is meant by the inexhaustibility of increasing diligence?
If there are bodhisattvas who diligently wish to hear the Dharma, they do not consider distance to be far, and they do not dislike water or fire.
Why is this?
Because they are without laziness or weariness, bodhisattvas increase and accumulate merit without retreating, because they gather and assist the merit of the multitude.
Why do they gather?
In order to enlighten and transform sentient beings, to enable them to attain liberation and enter nirvana.
Entering nirvana without indolence, with a firm mind that cannot be turned back, always seeking blessings without becoming weary, always abiding in great compassion, it is called accumulation.

Wherever the bodhisattva goes, whether walking, sitting, or rising, he does not forget the mind of the Way. In a single thought, he thinks of the Buddha's teachings and protects all without considering it troublesome. Therefore, it is called accumulation that is inexhaustible.
What is meant by 'cultivating all diligence that is inexhaustible'?
The merit established and the aspirations always present in all wisdom are therefore called 'inexhaustible.'
Just as the dragons return to rain the great ocean, it cannot be separately known how many drops there are, and counting them is inexhaustible;
The merit of all wisdom is like this, reaching inexhaustibility.
What is meant by 'establishing innumerable merits'?

The mind that engages in activities is for the sake of all, always harboring an impartial mind. The merit established is not apart from penetrating insight. The meritorious vows cultivated wish to cause sentient beings to all receive grace together. For this reason, it is called establishing innumerable merits.
What is meant by the mind seeking the perfections that are inexhaustible?
The four great elements of sentient beings are all inexhaustible. The incalculable enters these numbers.

One teaches the sentient beings of the trichiliocosm in this way, which is beyond measure. Innumerable such beings, a hundred times, a thousand times, ten thousand times, a hundred million times, an incalculable number of times, the number of those who are taught and liberated is very few;
Hearing this, one is not frightened or terrified, and practices diligently. This is called establishing innumerable merits that are inexhaustible.
What is meant by understanding wisdom that is infinite?

Because the merits of the bodhisattvas are inexhaustible. In this way, all the merits accumulated by all sentient beings who have attained universal knowledge, as well as the merits of the path of the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and arhats, are combined to form a single merit of the Buddha's hair.
Combining and accumulating these merits, each forming a single merit, one can form the Buddha's eyebrows.
With a thousand times the merit of the eyebrows, one can form the Buddha's uá¹£á¹‡Ä«á¹£a.
Why is this so?
Because none in the heavens above or the world below can bear to see the Buddha's uá¹£á¹‡Ä«á¹£a. For this reason, it is said that his merits are inexhaustible and his wisdom boundless.
Moreover, what is meant by boundless wisdom?
Even if all sentient beings in the trichiliocosm were to have deep faith in the Buddha, such faith in the Buddha would be a hundred times less than the merit of a single faithful follower.

Even if one were to serve and have faith in the eight kinds of people who fill the trichiliocosm, their wisdom would be a hundred times less than that of the eight kinds of people.ğŸ”½If the eight kinds of people were to fill the trichiliocosm, their wisdom would be a hundred times less than that of the stream-enterers.

If the trichiliocosm were filled with people seeking the path of the stream-enterers, the path of the once-returners, the path of the non-returners, and the path of the arhats, their wisdom would be a hundred times less than that of a single pratyekabuddha.

Even if the trichiliocosm were filled with pratyekabuddhas, it would still be less than the wisdom of a single bodhisattva who has given rise to the intention to achieve enlightenment.ğŸ”½Even if the trichiliocosm were filled with bodhisattvas who have given rise to the intention to achieve enlightenment, their wisdom would be a hundred times less than that of a bodhisattva who is irreversible.

Even if the trichiliocosm were filled with irreversible bodhisattvas, their wisdom would be a hundred times less than that of a single bodhisattva who is destined to achieve enlightenment in one lifetime.
Even if the beings in the trichiliocosm were to become candidates for one birth, their wisdom would be a hundred times less than that of a single TathÄgata's wisdom power.
Combining all powers and fearlessnesses, one enters the Buddha's Dharma and practices the essential wisdom.
Why is it so?
All omniscience is contained within the Buddha's mind.
If bodhisattvas hear this and are not frightened, fearful, terrified, or distressed, this is called cultivating inexhaustible wisdom.
Why is it said to cultivate inexhaustible wisdom?
It is because it enters the minds of all sentient beings.

Even if the thoughts of past sentient beings are limitless, if one gives rise to the intention for enlightenment, understands clearly, and fully comprehends the thoughts of these past sentient beings, it is the same as with all sentient beings, just like a single person, and such a comparison is beyond measure.
Sentient beings are all covered by desire, anger, and delusion. If there is a person who enters into the confusion of desire, anger, and delusion, and is deluded and confused by various defilements,

the bodhisattva gives rise to the intention to always use the wisdom of the Way to know the confusion of desire, anger, and delusion of sentient beings. This is called the great wisdom of the sagely illumination of wisdom.

If all sentient beings each give rise to the intention - whether the causes and conditions of good and evil, or what is caused by causes and conditions, what arises and what ceases - such wisdom, although dwelling in the midst of it, does not give rise to vexation, and is able to penetrate through it like empty space.
As for empty space, there is no place that is not empty.

It is the same with sagely wisdom. The mind that is illuminated and understood reaches all sentient beings of the three times without fail. Therefore, it is called wisdom that is inexhaustible and cannot be exhausted.
What is meant by the Buddha Dharma being also inexhaustible?
Fully possessing all six pÄramitÄs, seeking the Buddha Dharma,

If a bodhisattva from the initial generation of the mind cultivates skillful means, then sits under the bodhi tree, the merit of generating the mind is immeasurable, and all are fully endowed and accomplished in the Buddha Dharma. Therefore, it is said that the bodhisattva's union with the Buddha Dharma is inexhaustible.
Moreover, there is a bodhisattva who accumulates diligence and is also inexhaustible.

The merit established by the body is not considered difficult, the meritorious virtue expounded by the mouth is also not weary, and the mind diligently cultivates. The diligence of the three matters of body, speech, and mind is the foremost.
What is meant by mental diligence?
The mind is at ease.
What is meant by at ease?
It is used to seek Buddhahood.
What is meant by using to seek Buddhahood?
It is to expand the mind and be tranquil without doing anything.
What is meant by generating this?
Generating this mind means generating the mind of the Way, which is the great compassion of the bodhisattva.
What is meant by the stage of the bodhisattva?
It is said to be forbearance in believing and delighting in the non-self.
What is meant by giving rise to this?
Those who give rise to this are able to comprehensively embrace all sentient beings.
What is meant by abiding in this?
It is because one has attained mastery over all dharmas and does not consider birth and death to be arduous.
Those who give rise to this do not become attached to the three realms;
Those who give rise to this have no attachment to anything they possess.
Moreover, abiding in this means that when making offerings, one does not praise oneself for having such virtuous conduct;
Abiding in this means that one does not boast about one's own observance of precepts and harbor arrogance in one's mind;
Moreover, abiding in this means enduring various sufferings without giving rise to arrogance based on this practice.
It is said that abiding in this increases one's merit and virtue, which is vast and immeasurable.
Abiding in this means being committed to liberation, not apart from generosity, subduing the mind and controlling the thoughts;
Abiding in this means studying without becoming complacent, practicing in accordance with the teachings;
What is meant by 'abiding' is to practice according to the heard meaning without changing, without a different intention;
What is meant by 'abiding' is to study and contemplate the Dharma that cannot be expounded, and to consider skillful means as not difficult.

Cultivating without expectation, the Dharma that is proclaimed is enjoyed, recited, contemplated, and understood, without becoming weary and negligent, cultivating again and again without expecting any reward. These four things are what bodhisattvas practice.
Why is it so?
One who is able to give rise to this compassion and joy.
Moreover, 'abiding' means to contemplate with a mind that universally embraces great compassion;
Moreover, 'abiding' means to fully possess the five supernatural powers due to this, and to cultivate without birth and death;
Moreover, 'abiding' means to attain the four bases of mindfulness, to accord with the principles, and not to think about what should not be thought about.
Moreover, that place is where one knows the four right efforts without neglecting merit, and also does not suppress those without blessings and joy.
Why is it so?
Cultivating the middle way.
Moreover, that place is where one practices the spiritual powers as taught in the Buddha's Dharma without any expectations;
Moreover, that place is where one studies good virtues, with the faculties undisturbed, and is able to discern all that is not the Dharma without limit;
Moreover, that place is where one has the ten powers that cannot be overcome, and the mind harbors sagely wisdom;

Moreover, that place is where one seeks Buddha's enlightenment, and in all the practices undertaken, enters the various Dharma meanings without being arrogant, and accomplishes the seven factors of enlightenment.
Moreover, that place is where one seeks this morality and virtue, not thinking of those who come, stay, or leave, and also having no conceptualization;
Moreover, that place is where one aspires to be reverent, with a tranquil mind and without confusion;
Moreover, that place is where one wishes to attain right contemplation, clearly discern all dharmas, and seek their existence;
Moreover, that place is where one can extensively learn and then cultivate, always abiding by the Dharma and striving to cultivate the virtues of practice.
Moreover, that place is where one seeks the Dharma body and diminishes worldly attachments, with faith in the realization that conceptual attachments are formless;
Moreover, that place is where one's voice always wishes to adorn and express itself in accordance with the Dharma, reaching throughout the ten directions;
Moreover, that place is where one delights in practicing the Way, liberating those who are not yet liberated and bringing them to lasting peace.
Moreover, that place is where one does not associate with what is not right, and encourages the four demons.
What are the four demons?
First, the demon of the body; second, the demon of sinful defilements; third, the demon of death; fourth, the demon of the heavens.
Moreover, that place is where one abandons all evil habits and cultivates the roots of virtue, with all defilements peacefully extinguished and not giving rise to chaos;
Moreover, that place is where one universally sees the wisdom of the Way and observes the arising of various conditions;
Furthermore, in that place, one sees all that is entered and what is done in the world, and uses skillful means to deliver them;
Furthermore, in that place, one universally observes the Dharma of the Way and transforms according to the times. This is the inexhaustible vigor of the mind.

If one can be equipped in all places, one will ultimately have no difficulties, and will understand all that is done. One will not dwell in the wisdom of practice with deluded thoughts, nor will one waver. All practices are not apart from wisdom.
What is meant by bodhisattvas practicing without being apart from wisdom?
All meritorious practices are caused by this Dharma, and one always gives rise to supreme kindness for all.
Supreme kindness does not exhaust worldly affairs, and because of the wisdom of the Buddha's Way, one does not follow non-action. This is called the inexhaustible vigor of the bodhisattvas.

When expounding on the inexhaustibility of vigor, the ninety-six koá¹­Ä«s of celestial beings and worldly people all gave rise to the intention of unsurpassed, genuine, and perfect enlightenment. Thirty-two thousand sons of gods all attained the acceptance that dharmas are not produced from anywhere.
ÅšÄriputra further asked Bodhisattva AchimÃ²:
Is there any further meaning to the perfection of giving being inexhaustible?
AchimÃ² said:
It is because of sixteen things that it is inexhaustible, and cannot be reached by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
What are the sixteen?
First, when giving, one does not harbor a different mind but fully possesses the TathÄgata's Dharma giving.
Second, when giving, one does not give rise to the thought:
'For this reason, I will obtain blessed rewards.'
Third, when giving, one has universal compassion for all without harboring a different mind.
Fourth, when giving, one does not think of hoping to attain samÄdhi and meditative absorption.
Why is this?
One does not delight in being born in the Pure Abodes but always enjoys the human realm.
Fifth, when giving, one is able to penetrate and know the mental activities of sentient beings.
Sixth, when giving, one's mind is pure and harmonious.
Why is this?
They want to make their minds follow their own calculations, and also to make their bodies follow what their minds think.
Seventh, what they give is in accordance with the intentions of the recipients.
Why is this?
Their virtue surpasses that of the gods of form and formlessness.
Eighth, what they give is accompanied by tranquility and peace.
Why is this?
It surpasses the stage of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Ninth, what they give is not accompanied by a resentful mind.
Why is this?
They want to thoroughly understand and accomplish it.
Tenth, what they give is majestic and majestic, and no one can obstruct it.
Eleventh, with the giving of wisdom, they universally equalize all beings and establish the means to deliver all.
Twelfth, what they give is given to others according to their wishes and with a joyful and always correct and peaceful mind of giving and saving.
Why is this?
Because they are able to control their minds.
Thirteenth, what they give does not cut off the Three Jewels.
Why is this?
Not abandoning the lineage of the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One.
Fourteen, always being clear in one's giving, not harboring doubts or being confused.
Fifteen, giving in accordance with the Dharma teachings.
Why is it so?
Because one's practice accords with the meaning.
Sixteen, giving without not knowing, and in one's undertakings, delighting in the basis of wisdom.
Why is it so?
Because one wishes for one's wisdom to be inexhaustible and extremely vast.
These are the sixteen activities of bodhisattvas in the perfection of giving that are inexhaustible.
What is meant by meditation?
Because the mind is tranquil.
What is meant by spiritual powers?
Because of the completeness of wisdom.
What is meant by wisdom?
Seeing various forms is not penetrating.
Seeing the exhaustion of forms, the mind does not follow it, this is called penetrating.
Why is it so?
Because one does not take up practice and realization midway.
What one hears is all in the non-penetrating;
All sounds are ultimately unattainable, this is called penetration.
Being able to understand the mental activities of sentient beings is not penetration, but the mind eliminates this wisdom and does not create realization through the exhaustion of the mind.
Why is it so?
Not grasping arhatship, this is called penetration.
Being able to know one's own past causes and origins is not penetration, but not having any obstructions in the three times is called penetration;
Permeating all lands is not penetration, but although permeating all lands, understanding that they are nonexistent and having no concept of lands is called penetration;
Faithfully following all dharmas is not penetration, but penetratingly seeing the beginning and end of all dharmas is called penetration;
All actions with deluded thoughts are not penetration, but clearly understanding sentient beings and having no expectations is called penetration;

If one wishes to be reborn in the heavens, Åšakra, BrahmÄ, or the four heavenly kings, then this is not allowed. The bodhisattva knows all the holy wisdom cultivated by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and is able to comprehensively grasp this, which is called penetrating.
Being the leader of the assembly - what is meant by leader is because it is at the highest of all dharmas, and for this reason it is called the inexhaustible merit of penetrating wisdom.
The bodhisattva Aká¹£ayamati said to ÅšÄriputra:
Because of various disturbed thoughts, the bodhisattva therefore practices taming the mind, which is called dhyÄna. The wise one abandons all evil, which is called dhyÄna concentration.
Moreover, the bodhisattva practice cultivates abiding in concentration, and the mind is without change.
Why is it so?
Cultivating correct abiding, because of correctly abiding, one cultivates the six pÄramitÄs.
Correcting all dharmas, because of correcting, one practices the various dharmas;
Cultivating the bodhisattva practice, with an equal mind towards sentient beings, having an equal mind towards sentient beings, then one is equal to all dharmas;
Having already equally understood all dharmas, one knows the minds of bodhisattvas. Having known bodhisattvas, one is then able to thoroughly understand the aspirations of sentient beings.
Having known sentient beings, one then knows all dharmas. This is called practicing extensively and equally.
All types of sentient beings are equal to all dharmas, without acceptance or rejection. Abiding equally in all dharmas is called the samÄdhi of correct acceptance.
Emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness are said to be equal to birth and death. Being equal to birth and death is then equal to all dharmas. Having already been impartial and level,

the mind that is universally equal is equal to the minds of sentient beings. Having already been equal to the minds of sentient beings, it is then called equality. Therefore, it is said to be universally equal.
The mind's activities are level like empty space, like earth, water, fire, and wind, without love or hatred;
The mind that is equal has no worries or joys. The body has already abided without blinking in the Buddha lands, concentrated like samÄdhi.

They do not flatter or deceive, abide in the fundamental nature, are not arrogant or self-deprecating, are not foolish or evil, and do not speak much, but only wish to understand the fundamental source of the Dharma.

They know when it is the right time and when it is not, always in accordance with circumstances, not following any worldly defilements, transcending the eight worldly concerns - gain and loss, slander and praise, suffering and pleasure, fame and obscurity - abandoning all conditioned things, not delighting in confusion, those who follow this Dharma do not depart from samÄdhi.
Why is this?

They see all the practices established in the world, following their practice, continuing in samÄdhi, which no one can know. This is called the bodhisattva's skillful means, deeply entering wisdom and reaching the other shore.
If one wishes to enter samÄdhi and control one's mind, it is through supreme compassion and in accordance with causes and conditions.
Why is this?
It is for the sake of sentient beings, this meaning is called skillful means;
The practice of samÄdhi, tranquil and serene, is called sagely wisdom.
Relying on the Buddha's wisdom based on the establishment of samÄdhi is called skillful means;
Never seeking anything in the various dharmas is called wisdom.
Upholding concentration and using merit to transform and protect all dharmas is called skillful means;
The mind is at ease, not destroying the Dharma body, is called wisdom.
Abiding in samÄdhi and contemplating the Buddha's body, its various characteristics and marks, is called skillful means;
Vastly and constantly contemplating the Buddha's Dharma body is called wisdom.
In samÄdhi, contemplating the Buddha's various sounds like the voice of BrahmÄ is called skillful means;
Contemplating that all dharmas are beyond words is called wisdom.
Abiding in samÄdhi, the mind like vajra, is called skillful means;
Although attaining meditation, not forgetting the world, sentient beings, and the multitude, is called wisdom.
While in samÄdhi, to fulfill one's original vow and nurture all beings is skillful means;
To understand in dhyÄna that all beings are devoid of self is wisdom.
To roam in samÄdhi without abandoning the dharmas is skillful means;
To understand that there are no beginnings or ends, and no roots or origins, is wisdom.
To cultivate samÄdhi and contemplate all buddha-lands as pure is skillful means;
To understand that all buddha-lands are ultimately non-existent is wisdom.
To abide in samÄdhi and only cultivate and adorn the bodhi tree is skillful means;
To be free from the defilements of the body and desires is wisdom.
To contemplate the turning of the Dharma wheel while in samÄdhi is skillful means;
To practice dhyÄna and turn without turning is wisdom.
To abide in samÄdhi and wish to see the bodhisattvas adorned with the marks is skillful means; to deliver from suffering without afflictions is the TathÄgata's dhyÄna.

The meditation of the TathÄgata is to understand all dharmas, never to crave or think of defilements, to know the pleasures of the senses, and to eliminate all conceptual thoughts of dharmas. This is called meditation. This is the wisdom that gives birth to bodhisattvas.
Great beings use their one-pointed minds to be different from the defilements of dharmas. This is called the inexhaustible meditation.
It does not allow any demons to take advantage, and thus it creates the dharma vessel for right enlightenment.
Why is this so?
Because it contains everything.
When the true man was expounding the inexhaustible perfection of meditation, forty thousand bodhisattvas attained the samÄdhi of solar illumination.
What is meant by the samÄdhi of solar illumination?
Just as when the sun rises, the light of lamps, torches, stars, and moonlight is obscured in the darkness;
when bodhisattvas have attained this samÄdhi, all the myriad sages are all obscured.
Why is this so?
Because his wisdom is lofty and his illumination is vast, the wisdom-illumination of all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is all obscured, and therefore it is called the samÄdhi of solar illumination.
The bodhisattva who has already abided in the perfection of tranquility can attain all samÄdhi concentrations.

One who understands conditioned activities does not dispute. If you want to avoid disputes, nothing is better than self-restraint. If you want to know that non-speech is excellent, nothing is better than not speaking.
Why is it so?

Those who do not delight in speech guard their own body and speech. Those who do not wish to dwell should not stay in that dwelling. Those who do not wish to move should be careful not to change. Those who have no expectations also have no thoughts. Therefore, it is called equanimity.

Those who do not wish to be confused by form should correctly abide firmly. Those who have already abided firmly will then reach it. Those who do not delight in change should always be careful and cautious, if they aspire for tranquility.
Those who nurture themselves should not praise themselves.
Those who do not wish to be lowly should not be arrogant. Those who are neither arrogant nor lowly are endowed with the true Dharma.
Those who do not delight in harm cannot be reprimanded. Those who delight in peace and comfort do not make mistakes in their actions.
Those who make no mistakes have no doubts.
Those who have no doubts understand that there is no basis, so they have nothing to lose. They are equal to the three times without any distinction.
Those who are equal to the three times neither increase nor decrease. They do not abide in form, feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness, and there is no distinction.
